IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: Create, find, and support programs that improve the health and well being of children.We accomplish our mission by caring for families and keeping them close to their children at our 20-bedroom "home away from home", caring for the parents of the most critically ill and injured children at our House Within the Hospital, located above the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit at the Golisano Children's Hospital at Strong, providing a Family Lounge on the Pediatric Floor at the Golisano Children's Hospital at Strong that brings the caring spirit of our two Houses to all families with children in treatment and funding programs that improve the health outcomes for children in our area.
IRS990.MissionDescription: Ronald McDonald House Charities of Rochester NY, Inc. (the "Organization") reaches out to the community to promote the health and well-being of children and their families by providing a home-away-from-home for families whose children are receiving medical treatment at area medical facilities, and by supporting other programs that help children. The Ronald McDonald House (the "Westmoreland House"), is a 20-bedroom facility that provides temporary lodging to families who must leave their own homes to seek medical care for their children. In January 2005, the Organization opened an additional facility, a 7-bedroom "House Within the Hospital," at the Golisano Children's Hospital at Strong, for families of critically ill or injured children receiving treatment at the hospital. The Organization also makes grants to nonprofit organizations that improve the health outcomes of children in the Greater Rochester community.
IRS990.Description: OPERATIONS - The Organization owns and operates the 20-bedroom Ronald McDonald House and the 7-bedroom House Within the Hospital. Both facilities provide temporary lodging to families of critically ill children who must leave their own communities to seek medical care for their children - the Westmoreland House in close proximity to Strong Memorial Hospital and the House Within the Hospital physically located within the hospital. Both facilities serve families of children receiving treatment at the Golisano Children's Hospital at Strong and the Westmoreland House serves families with children in treatment at all other medical facilities. In 2010 the Ronald McDonald Houses provided a total of 1,185 family lodging periods, which includes multiple stays for some families. Families came from 19 counties across New York State, as well as Canada and Germany for "state of the art" treatment practiced at the Golisano Children's Hospital and other area medical facilities.Families of critically ill children age 18 and under are eligible to stay at both facilities. They must be referred by a physician and be undergoing inpatient or outpatient care at a medical facility. For the Westmoreland House, a nominal donation of $10 per night per family is requested, which only partly defrays actual operating costs. However, no family is ever turned away if they cannot afford payment. No room donation is requested at the House Within the Hospital. The House is an approved lodging facility for families covered by Medicaid.Funds are solicited through the Heartbeats newsletter published twice a year. In-kind donations of goods and services valued at over $591,930 were received in 2010. This amount excludes the value of volunteer hours noted below. Major in-kind donations include waste disposal, long-distance phone cards for guests, beverages (milk and soda drinks), daily newspapers, carpet cleaning, cleaning supplies, household paper goods, pagers, home cooked dinners 4-6 days a week, books and games, and retail space and supplies for special events.A large group of volunteers help to support the Organization's staff and guests by providing housekeeping, office assistance, gardening, solicitation of in-kind goods, and repair and maintenance of the facilities. Volunteers provided approximately 46,200 hours of service to the Houses in 2010, which dramatically reduced the need to hire staff to complete the many varied activities.The Organization reviews its strategic plans on a continuing basis. In the past, this review has identified areas for potential program expansion both inside the Houses and in the broader community the Organization serves, leading, for example, to the establishment of the House Within the Hospital. It has also helped the Organization enhance service delivery of its existing programs.

Activity2.Description: GRANT MAKING - The Organization's mission is to create, find, and support programs that directly improve the health and well being of children. While the Ronald McDonald House and the House Within the Hospital are its cornerstone programs, the Organization recognizes that their intensive support can reach out to only 27 families at any given time. To meet its broader mission, the Organization also provides grants to nonprofits in the greater Rochester, New York area. In 2010 grants from the Organization to 15 organizations provided support to over 7,200 children. Money used for grant making comes from special promotions held by local McDonald franchises, special designated fundraising activities and a matching grant account funded by the National Chapter of Ronald McDonald House Charities in Oak Brook, IL.

IRS990ScheduleA.GeneralExplanation: Schedule A, Part II, Line 10, Explanation of Other Income: Other Income and Net Special Events Income

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Identifier: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Organization has adopted investment and spending policies for endowment assets that attempt to provide a predictable stream of funding to programs supported by its endowment while seeking to maintain the purchasing power of the investment portfolio. Endowment assets include those assets of donor-restricted funds that the organization must hold in perpetuity. Under this policy, as approved by the Board of Directors, the endowment assets are invested in a manner that is intended to produce results, net of fees, which meet or exceed the composite benchmarks for each asset class while assuming a moderate level of investment risk.

Part X, Line 2: The Internal Revenue Service has determined that the Organization is qualified as a charity exempt under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, and has also determined that the Organization is publicly supported. As a result, no provision for federal or state income taxes has been made. The Organization has also been classified as an organization that is not a private foundation. FASB ASC #740, Income Taxes, requires entities to disclose in their financial statements the nature of any uncertainties in their tax position. Tax years including 2007 and later are subject to examination by tax authorities. Areas that IRS and state tax authorities consider when examining tax returns of a charity include, but may not be limited to, tax-exempt status and the existence and amount of unrelated business income. The Organization does not believe that it has any uncertain tax positions with respect to these or other matters, and has not recorded any unrecognized tax benefits or liability for penalties or interest. The Organization is not aware of any circumstances or events that make it reasonably possible that tax benefits may increase or decrease within 12 months of the date of these financial statements.

RecipientTable.PurposeOfGrant: Inclusive sports clinics/Scholarships for therapeutic riding lessons
Pediatric Social work fund/SMILEmobile/Child Life SpecialistPediatric Social work fundPediatric Social work fund

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Procedure for Monitoring Grants in the U.S.:
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: RMHC requires detailed accounting of all funds awarded. A follow-up form is automatically sent to all grant recipients 30 days after the completion of the program, not to exceed one year from the date of the award. It is understood that any funds not used in the manner specified in the grant agreement will be returned to RMHC. RMHC also may monitor and conduct an evaluation of operations under each grant, which may include a visit from RMHC personnel to observe the program, discuss the program with recipient personnel and review financial and other records and materials connected with the activities financed by the grant.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Form 990 is reviewed in detail by the Audit Committee and the Director of Finance and then presented in overview form to the full Board of Directors with complete copies made available upon request.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: All Board Members and staff annually sign conflict of interest statements. There is not a formal monitoring process. Through the conflict of interest agreements, the Organization is not aware of any actual or potential conflicts by staff or board members.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Executive Director's performance is reviewed by the Board President and Vice President. Input relative to her performance is received from the Executive Committee and Board Committee Chairs. The appraisal, as well as recommendation for salary increase, was reviewed with the Chair of the Human Resources Committee. Comparables of Executive Director positions within this geographic region and like not-for-profits were assessed. The proposed merit increase took into account overall performance as well as comparables. The Director of Finance's performance is reviewed annually by the Executive Director. Salary and salary increases are reviewed with the Human Resources Committee.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Organization's governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements are on file with NYS Charities and GuideStar. The documents are also available from the Organization upon request.
